abstract: <jats:sec><jats:title>Background</jats:title><jats:p>In Mexico, species of four families of free-living calanoid copepods have been recorded as inhabitants of several freshwater systems. These families are Centropagidae, Temoridae, Pseudodiaptomidae and Diaptomidae. The genera<jats:italic>Leptodiaptomus</jats:italic>and<jats:italic>Mastigodiaptomus</jats:italic>are the most speciose diaptomid genera in Mexico, and they inhabit natural and artificial lakes, ephemeral ponds, springs, and caverns.<jats:italic>Leptodiaptomus</jats:italic>is considered as an endemic Nearctic genus, whereas<jats:italic>Mastigodiaptomus</jats:italic>is a widely distributed Neotropical genus in the southern USA, Mexico, the Caribbean Islands and Central America. Based on new and recent evidence,<jats:italic>Mastigodiaptomus</jats:italic>diversity has been underestimated: six species of the genus were known before 2000. In this work three new<jats:italic>Mastigodiaptomus</jats:italic>species have been described from different regions of Mexico by using integrative taxonomy. We also gave amended diagnosis of<jats:italic>M. nesus</jats:italic>Bowman (1986) and<jats:italic>M. patzcuarensis</jats:italic>s. str. (Kiefer, 1938).</jats:p></jats:sec><jats:sec><jats:title>Methods</jats:title><jats:p>In this work, the taxonomic status of the species was clarified using modern, integrative method based on the COI gene as a DNA marker, plus micro-structural analysis (based on SEM and ligth microscopy).</jats:p></jats:sec><jats:sec><jats:title>Results</jats:title><jats:p>Three new species of<jats:italic>Mastigodiaptomus</jats:italic>were described based on genetic and morphological analyses:<jats:italic>M. alexei</jats:italic>sp. n.,<jats:italic>M. ha</jats:italic>sp. n. and<jats:italic>M. cihuatlan</jats:italic>sp. n. Also amended description of<jats:italic>M. nesus</jats:italic>, morphological variation of<jats:italic>M. patzcuarensis</jats:italic>s. str., and a comparison of them with all known sequences within the genus are provided. These new findings show that in<jats:italic>Mastigodiaptomus</jats:italic>differences in several cuticular microstructures of several appendages (such as the antennules, the fifth legs, or the urosomites of these copepods) agree with the interspecific genetic divergence >3% observed in sequences of the COI gene, and the integration of this information is a powerful tool in species delineation.</jats:p></jats:sec>
title: Remarks onMastigodiaptomus(Calanoida: Diaptomidae) from Mexico using integrative taxonomy, with a key of identification and three new species
